tier_1.content: Sellers want {marketPressure}% more than what cards recently sold for, but not many people are buying (buyer interest score: {liquidityScore}/100). This means the cards are overpriced. Better deals exist elsewhere.
advice_seller: You'll probably wait a long time unless you drop your price
advice_buyer: Pass on this one‚Äîyour money is better spent elsewhere

tier_2.content: Sellers want {marketPressure}% more than recent sale prices, but buyers aren't interested (buyer interest score: {liquidityScore}/100). The cards are priced too high. Wait for prices to come down or find better options.
advice_buyer: Wait it out. Prices will likely drop
advice_collector: If you want it for your collection: Wait it out. Prices will likely drop

tier_3.content: Sellers want {marketPressure}% more than recent sales, but buyers aren't biting (buyer interest score: {liquidityScore}/100). At this price range, buyers do their homework and won't overpay. These asking prices will probably drop or sit unsold for months.
advice_seller: Price it fairly from the start
At this price level, overpriced cards sit forever
advice_buyer: Be patient. These prices will come down

tier_4.content: Sellers want {marketPressure}% more than what these cards recently sold for, and not many buyers are looking ({liquidityScore}/100 buyer interest). For expensive cards like this, it's normal to have fewer buyers‚Äîbut when you combine that with inflated prices, it means sellers are testing the market and will probably need to lower their expectations.
advice_seller: Price it right from the start
Experienced buyers at this level know the market and won't chase overpriced cards
advice_collector: Wait it out. Expensive cards often get cheaper when sellers realize nobody's paying their asking price

tier_5.content: eBay listings are {marketPressure}% higher than what similar cards sold for at auctions, and not many people are watching ({liquidityScore}/100). For really expensive cards, there are fewer eBay sales‚Äîlots of trophy cards sell through auction houses instead. These sellers might be hoping someone pays extra to buy on eBay instead of waiting for an auction.
advice_collector: Check what these cards sold for at Heritage, PWCC, or Goldin auctions first
Big auction sales are usually more reliable for pricing trophy cards than eBay listings

tier_1.content: Prices are pretty normal (only {marketPressure}% vs. recent sales), but not many people are buying (buyer interest: {liquidityScore}/100). Even though prices are fair, the cards aren't selling well. Probably means the card is losing popularity or too many copies are for sale.
advice_seller: Expect slow sales
Even with fair prices, cheap cards need lots of buyers to move
advice_buyer: No rush‚Äîthese will still be here

tier_2.content: Prices are reasonable ({marketPressure}% vs. recent sales), but sales are slow (buyer interest: {liquidityScore}/100). Even at fair prices, cards aren't moving. Could mean buyer interest is fading or too many are available.
advice_buyer: Not ideal for flips. Even good deals might take a while to resell
advice_collector: Could be a quiet buying opportunity
Fair prices without hype often age well

tier_3.content: Prices look reasonable ({marketPressure}% vs. recent sales), with moderate buyer activity ({liquidityScore}/100). At this price range, fewer people can afford $500-$2K cards, so slower sales are normal. This isn't necessarily 'people losing interest'‚Äîit's just that the pool of buyers is naturally smaller.
advice_buyer: Expect to hold it for 30-60 days even at a fair price
Factor that wait time into your plans
advice_collector: This is often a good situation‚Äîfair prices without crazy hype
If it's a historically important card or proven star, slow and steady is actually good

tier_4.content: Prices are fair ({marketPressure}% vs. recent sales), with moderate buyer activity ({liquidityScore}/100). For expensive cards, slower buying is normal and expected. Fewer people can spend $2K-$10K, and those who can take their time deciding.
advice_seller: At this level, waiting 60-120+ days to sell is typical for fairly-priced cards
Fair pricing helps, but patience is required
advice_collector: Great environment. Fair prices + low drama = healthy long-term investment

tier_5.content: Prices match recent sales ({marketPressure}% vs. recent sales), with limited but serious buyer interest ({liquidityScore}/100). Trophy-level cards don't sell often. When they do, it's usually through auction houses or private sales, not eBay.
advice_seller: eBay might not be the best place
Major auction houses (Heritage, PWCC, Goldin) usually find better buyers for expensive cards
advice_collector: Fair prices on trophy cards are rare opportunities
Make absolutely sure the card is real and in the condition claimed

tier_1.content: Prices are in the middle range ({marketPressure}% vs. recent sales) and buyers seem moderately active ({liquidityScore}/100). This is a normal, stable market. Nothing special happening‚Äîuse your normal judgment.

tier_2.content: Prices are in the middle range ({marketPressure}% vs. recent sales) and buyers seem moderately interested ({liquidityScore}/100). This is a normal, stable market. Not hot, not cold‚Äîgood for patient buyers and sellers with fair prices.

tier_3.content: Prices are in the middle range ({marketPressure}% vs. recent sales) and buyer interest is moderate ({liquidityScore}/100). For cards at this price, moderate buyer interest is typical‚Äîthere just aren't as many people buying $500-$2K cards as there are buying $50 cards. That's normal.
advice_seller: If you're selling, expect to wait 30-60 days to find a buyer

tier_4.content: Prices are in the middle range ({marketPressure}% vs. recent sales) with moderate buyer interest ({liquidityScore}/100). At this price level, 'moderate' buyer interest is actually healthy‚Äîserious buyers exist, but they take their time.
advice_seller: If you're listing a card, expect 60-120+ days to be normal
That's not a red flag‚Äîit's just how this price range works

tier_5.content: Prices match recent comparables ({marketPressure}% vs. recent sales) with measured interest ({liquidityScore}/100). For trophy cards, eBay sales only tell part of the story‚Äîmany sales happen through auction houses or privately. Use this eBay data as one piece of information, not the whole picture.
advice_collector: Check recent Heritage, PWCC, or Goldin auction results for additional price confirmation at this level

tier_1.content: The prices are all over the place (confidence: {confidence}/100) and asking prices are {marketPressure}% vs FMV. This usually means your search is mixing different card types, conditions, or variations together. Try making your search more specific to get better results.
advice_seller: Be careful pricing your card based on outliers
Buyers will question your price and negotiate aggressively
Before listing, tighten your search to match your exact card
advice_buyer: Only buy if the deal is obviously mispriced and easy to verify
Otherwise, the risk outweighs the reward
advice_collector: This is a 'pause and research' moment
Waiting for cleaner data usually leads to better buying decisions
No need to rush unless the card is extremely scarce

tier_1.content: Cards priced below FMV are selling {absorptionBelow}x faster than new listings appear ({salesBelow} sales vs {belowFMV} listings), while higher-priced cards aren't selling quickly ({absorptionAbove} absorption, {salesAbove} sales vs {aboveFMV} listings). Average asking price is {marketPressure}% vs FMV.
advice_seller: Cards priced near or below fair value sell much faster
Overpricing usually leads to long wait times
If you want a quick sale, price competitively
advice_buyer: This is a good buying setup
Buy below fair value and sell close to it
Avoid premium pricing‚Äîthose listings tend to stall
advice_collector: A solid time to buy if you stick to fair prices
Ignore overpriced listings; they don't reflect real demand
Patient buyers have the advantage here

tier_1.content: The market for this card is very hot. Asking prices are {marketPressure}% above FMV, and are supported by strong demand and good liquidity ({liquidityScore}/100). Sellers currently have the upper hand because there are plenty of buyers and lots of sales happening, which helps support these high prices. Prices may still be rising, but they could start to drop if buyer interest or liquidity slows down.
advice_seller: This is a strong selling window
Buyers are accepting higher prices right now
Consider selling while demand is hot
advice_buyer: Flips are possible, but timing matters
You need to buy and resell quickly
Miss the timing, and you risk holding overpriced inventory
advice_collector: You're paying extra to get a card immediately
If you don't need the card now, waiting is usually safer
Great cards often come back down once hype fades

tier_1.content: Available cards are priced {absMarketPressure}% below FMV and lots of buyers are active (liquidity: {liquidityScore}/100). This is a rare opportunity: cards are underpriced and selling fast. This could mean a player is breaking out or performing well.
advice_seller: You could be leaving money on the table at current prices‚Äîconsider your opinion of the player's potential
Expect fast sales, even if you raise your price slightly
If you're listing now, consider pricing closer to fair value‚Äîor just above it
advice_buyer: This is an excellent setup
Buy quickly at current prices and aim for fast resale
Delays matter here‚Äîonce sellers adjust, margins shrink
advice_collector: This is one of the better times to buy if you're optimistic about the player's potential
You're entering below fair value in a market with real demand
Acting sooner usually beats waiting in conditions like this

tier_1.content: Prices are fair ({marketPressure}% vs FMV) and there's plenty of buyer activity (liquidity: {liquidityScore}/100). This is a healthy, well-functioning market where both buyers and sellers are active. Prices accurately reflect current demand: good conditions for both buying and selling.
advice_seller: Fair pricing is being rewarded with steady sales
No need to overthink timing‚Äîthis is a good environment to list
Well-presented listings should move at reasonable prices
advice_buyer: Opportunities exist, but they're not automatic
Profits depend on buying well, not on market imbalance
Focus on small edges rather than big swings
advice_collector: A comfortable, low-stress time to buy
You're unlikely to overpay or miss out by waiting briefly
Buy based on preference, not fear of price movement

liquidity_popup.title: How Easy Is It to Sell This Card?

tier_1.content: This score shows how hard or easy it might be to **sell your card** at a fair price. For cheap cards, a high score is normal‚Äîlow scores usually mean people are losing interest in the card.

tier_2.content: This score shows how hard or easy it might be to **sell your card** at a fair price. This price range has lots of buying and selling activity‚Äîyour score directly relates to how fast you can expect to sell.

tier_3.content: This score shows how hard or easy it might be to **sell your card** at a fair price. At this price level, lower scores are expected‚Äîfewer people can spend $500-$2K, and they take longer to decide. A medium score is normal and healthy.

tier_4.content: This score shows how realistic eBay is as a place to sell your card. For expensive cards, many sales happen through auction houses or private deals, not eBay. A lower eBay score doesn't mean the card is hard to sell‚Äîjust that eBay might not be the main marketplace.

tier_5.content: This score only reflects eBay activity, which is just a small part of the trophy card market. Major auction houses (Heritage, PWCC, Goldin) often work better for finding buyers at this price level. Use these scores as extra information, not the main story.
